rsbNotes.title: Judges 10:6–12:7
rsbNotes.text:
10:6–12:7 Cf. 1 Sam. 12:11. The list of idols Israel followed (10:6) and the internal chaos of Israel became more pronounced (12:1–7). Jephthah brought only six years of peace (12:7) instead of peace for a generation (3:11, 30; 5:31; 8:28). Finally, Jephthah rashly and sinfully sacrificed his daughter (11:30–40 note).

Many things about Jephthah are reminiscent of Gideon, Abimelech, or Saul. Jephthah like Gideon was a “mighty man of valor” (6:12; 11:1). Both men made the Ephraimites angry by not calling them out to participate in battle (8:1–3; 12:1–6). Jephthah and Abimelech were both outcast sons, one born to a concubine and the other to a harlot. They gathered to themselves bands of adventurers (9:4; 11:3). Both Jephthah and Saul were made leaders in Mizpah (11:11; 1 Sam. 10:17). Both men faced Ammonites as their first adversaries (11:12–29; 1 Sam. 11:1–11). Jepthah and Saul each made an unwise vow that returned to threaten their firstborn, and each offered an unlawful sacrifice (11:30–40; 1 Sam. 13:8–14; 14:24–25).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:1
rsbNotes.text:
11:1 a mighty warrior. This is what Gideon was called (6:12).

son of a prostitute. Jephthah’s heritage made him an outcast (v. 2).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:3
rsbNotes.text: 11:3 worthless fellows. Another similarity between Jephthah and Abimelech was their followers (9:4).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:9
rsbNotes.text: 11:9 the Lord gives them. Jephthah showed his faith that it was God who gave him victory.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:10
rsbNotes.text: 11:10 The Lord will be witness. The elders were swearing an oath in order to confirm a covenant.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:11
rsbNotes.text: 11:11 Jephthah spoke all his words before the Lord at Mizpah. The covenant is confirmed before the Lord in Mizpah. Years later the people made Saul king, also before the Lord, at Mizpah (1 Sam. 10:17).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:12–29
rsbNotes.text: 11:12–29 For the historical background to this conflict, see Num. 20:14–21; 21:10–35; Deut. 2:16–3:11. At the time of Jephthah, the Ammonites hoped to extend their territory into what once had been their land, but had now been Israel’s for three hundred years. Jephthah countered Ammonite demands by rehearsing this history and showing that they took no more than what the God of Israel had given them and, having been instructed by Him (Deut. 2:18–19), did not take anything from Ammon.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:12
rsbNotes.text: 11:12 king of the Ammonites. Like Saul, Jephthah’s first adversary was the Ammonites (1 Sam. 11:1–11). Gilead was the region threatened in Saul’s story as well.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:23
rsbNotes.text: 11:23 the Lord, the God of Israel. Warfare was viewed as a battle between the gods of the opposing forces. If Israel won, it was because the God of Israel had done it, and no one could dispute the result (v. 24). See v. 21.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:27
rsbNotes.text: 11:27 The Lord, the Judge, decide this day. See vv. 21, 23. Jephthah declared that God was the Judge over all peoples and gods. Here the word is used in a legal sense, as in handing down a decision, although God would ultimately be a deliverer as well (vv. 32–33). The Book of Judges affirms that God is the true King (8:23) and true Judge, who alone could solve Israel’s woes.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:29
rsbNotes.text: 11:29 Spirit of the Lord. See 3:10 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:30–40
rsbNotes.text: 11:30–40 Jephthah defeated the Ammonites, but in the process made a rash vow to the Lord and sacrificed his daughter as a burnt offering. God was not to be worshiped in the way the pagans worshiped their gods, namely, by human sacrifice (Deut. 12:31; 18:10; Ps. 106:37–38). As a deliverer, Jephthah did not show the people how to keep the covenant, despite giving evidence of his faith (vv. 10–11, 21, 23, 27). Like Jephthah, Saul also made a rash vow that turned out to be a threat to his own child (1 Sam. 14:24–45).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:35
rsbNotes.text:
11:35 tore his clothes. This was the sign of mourning over death.

opened my mouth. Although vows were sacred (Deut. 23:21–23), Jephthah’s action was wrong. Human sacrifice was absolutely forbidden in Israel (v. 39 note). It is evil to keep an evil vow. Unlawful oaths and vows must not be made or, if made, not kept (cf. Matt. 14:1–12).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:36
rsbNotes.text: 11:36 do to me according to what has gone out of your mouth. That is, “offer me as a sacrifice” (vv. 30–31).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:37
rsbNotes.text: 11:37 weep for my virginity. This probably means to lament that she would never marry or have children (vv. 38, 39).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 11:39
rsbNotes.text: 11:39 according to his vow. Though stated delicately, the text is clear: Jephthah sacrificed his daughter as a burnt offering. It is observed that she was a virgin, but this was not the content of the vow. Human sacrifice was sin, an imitation of pagan practice (11:30–40 note; Deut. 12:31; Ps. 106:38).

rsbNotes.title: Judges 12:1
rsbNotes.text: 12:1 men of Ephraim. Like Gideon, Jephthah had trouble with Ephraim (8:1–5); unlike Gideon, they brought it to civil war. Unity was sorely lacking in Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 12:1–7
rsbNotes.text:
12:1–7 Following immediately after the sacrifice of his daughter (11:30–40), this story implies that Jephthah’s struggle with Ephraim and his abbreviated judgeship (v. 7) were God’s judgment on him for sacrificing his daughter. Ps. 78 (esp. vv. 9–11, 67) reflects on Ephraim’s failure to fight and explains God’s rejection of Ephraim as Israel’s leader. Judah, the tribe of David, and not Ephraim would lead Israel (Ps. 78:68–72).

Why. See 8:1 for an almost identical question put to Gideon.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 12:4
rsbNotes.text: 12:4 the midst of Ephraim and Manasseh. The Gileadites were descended from Joseph, as were Ephraim and Manasseh.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 12:5
rsbNotes.text: 12:5 fords of the Jordan. Gilead was on the east side of the Jordan, Ephraim on the west.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 12:6
rsbNotes.text: 12:6 Shibboleth . . . Sibboleth. The Ephraimites could be recognized by the way certain words were pronounced in their dialect.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 12:7
rsbNotes.text: 12:7 Jephthah judged Israel six years. Previous judges led for forty or eighty years, and peace lasted a generation or two. Jephthah’s abbreviated rule, the increased number of gods being worshiped, and the civil war with Ephraim contribute to a picture of Israel’s downward spiral.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 12:8–15
rsbNotes.text: 12:8–15 Ibzan, Elon, and Abdon are briefly mentioned (10:1–5 note). Nothing more is known about these men. They bring the total of judges mentioned in the Book of Judges to twelve.

rsbNotes.title: Judges 12:14
rsbNotes.text: 12:14 seventy donkeys. Abdon wielded virtually royal power and wealth (10:4).
